In Julia, Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.

In Julia, you can use the `Dates.year` and `Dates.month` functions to get the year and month parts of a DateTime object and then convert these to strings and join them together into a string representing the desired "yyyymm" format. Here's how you could do it:

```julia
using DataFrames, Dates

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = map(x -> string(Dates.year(x)) * string(Dates.month(x)), df.dt)
end
```
This function `add_yearmonth` takes a DataFrame as input and adds a new column `:ym`. It uses the `map` function to apply a function that extracts the year and month from each DateTime in the column `:dt`, converts these values to strings, then concatenates them together into "yyyymm" format.
